commit.message:
recover-broken-vdb: skip file on UnicodeDecodeError

Not being able to decode it means file(1) returned some Unicode gibberish
which certainly means it's not going to be anything telling us it's
ELF or dynamically linked, hence not interesting for our purposes.

Closes: https://github.com/thesamesam/recover-broken-vdb/issues/6
Signed-off-by: Sam James <sam@gentoo.org>

commit.message:
fix_vdb: pass files as separate arguments to recover-broken-vdb-scanelf.sh

This may help for packages with a very long list of files.

Bug: https://bugs.gentoo.org/830004

commit.message:
NEWS: update for 0.0.9

Signed-off-by: Sam James <sam@gentoo.org>

setup.cfg: update for 0.0.9

Signed-off-by: Sam James <sam@gentoo.org>

NEWS: update for 0.0.9

Signed-off-by: Sam James <sam@gentoo.org>

recover-broken-vdb: hint if no need to rebuild world

Signed-off-by: Sam James <sam@gentoo.org>

recover-broken-vdb: add CONTENTS sanity check

Signed-off-by: Sam James <sam@gentoo.org>

recover-broken-vdb: minor style tweak

Signed-off-by: Sam James <sam@gentoo.org>

recover-broken-vdb: drop 'any-so' condition

We're already checking this *more precisely* in
find_corrupt_pkgs (based on file(1) output rather
than a regex for if the path is ".so-like")...

... and we already had a bug from spreading this logic
all over the place, so let's just drop it.

Signed-off-by: Sam James <sam@gentoo.org>

recover-broken-vdb: fix early-bail out case in fix_vdb

We can only return/bail out early if we have NEEDED
*and* we're not installing anything .so-like.

We were missing the 'return' being only in
the other branch.

Signed-off-by: Sam James <sam@gentoo.org>

recover-broken-vdb: add additional broken case

Signed-off-by: Sam James <sam@gentoo.org>

recover-broken-vdb: refactor into Package object

Signed-off-by: Sam James <sam@gentoo.org>

recover-broken-vdb: refactor broken-detection logic

Thanks-to: Hank Leininger <hlein@korelogic.com>
Signed-off-by: Sam James <sam@gentoo.org>

recover-broken-vdb: match scan tool's logic (for now)

This makes things a bit slower but it means we're
consistent.

In b714bc27d7fdc7238ec240e0033f6793255cb472, we reverted
the change I made because I fixed the conflict between
the two in the wrong direction. Now the recovery tool
agrees with the scan tool.

Reported-by: Hank Leininger <hlein@korelogic.com>
Signed-off-by: Sam James <sam@gentoo.org>

Revert "bin/recover-broken-vdb-find-broken.sh: fix condition for skipping"

It's possible for valid (broken) entries to have some files
and not others. I was making the two tools consistent, but
the error is actually on the _Python_ side.

This reverts commit 9f4ff51d46f4bf094851be63ec42924024c4a846.

Signed-off-by: Sam James <sam@gentoo.org>

recover-broken-vdb: don't abort on blank entries

This can happen for some e.g. executable-only packages,
it seems (at least if installed with older Portage versions).

Bug: https://bugs.gentoo.org/815493
Signed-off-by: Sam James <sam@gentoo.org>

setup.cfg: update for 0.0.8

Signed-off-by: Sam James <sam@gentoo.org>

This means emerge ... $(recover-broken-vdb-find-broken.sh) still works.

Signed-off-by: Sam James <sam@gentoo.org>

bin/recover-broken-vdb-find-broken.sh: drop 'non-critical' check

No-op and we're checking the wrong variable too, but this
would only be needed if the sed were less strict.
